message.content: This question requires knowledge about the formation of fossils. When liquefied soil flows over carcasses and then dries, it can become fossilized. Fossilization occurs when minerals from the soil replace the organic material of the carcass, preserving it over millions of years. Option (A) is incorrect because lakes are formed by bodies of water, not by soil flowing over carcasses. Option (B) is incorrect because diamonds are formed under high pressure and heat, not by soil and carcasses. Option (C) is unrelated to the process of fossilization.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the process of fossilization. When liquefied soil flows over carcasses and then dries, it can create the conditions necessary for fossilization. The soil hardens and preserves the remains of the carcasses, turning them into fossils over time. Option (A) is incorrect because lakes are bodies of water and not related to fossilization. Option (B) is incorrect because diamonds are formed under high pressure and temperatures deep within the Earth's mantle. Option (C) is incorrect because bubbles are formed by gases trapped within a liquid and not related to fossilization.
